title: Was smoking eliminated by young people, as Tim Kane says?
text: Tim Kane states that his efforts to raise the age of purchase of tobacco products from 18 to 21 are aimed at reducing the use of cybercigarette by adolescents. In a radio interview held on 29 May at John Frederick's Fair in Portsmouth, he said: "The phenomenon of e-sigretting has wiped out all the progress we have made in reducing youth smoking." We've verified the fact that battery tools have really wiped out the gains in cutting adolescent smoking. Kate Stuntz, Press Secretary of Karen, said that the Senator ' s statement was based on a February report on centres for disease control and prevention of tobacco use since 2011 by middle and secondary school students. The CDC concluded that "a significant increase in the use of e-cigarette among United States youth, combined with no change in the use of other tobacco products during the period 2017-2018, has removed recent progress in reducing the overall use of tobacco products among young people." The CDC conducts an annual survey on tobacco use by middle and secondary school students and wonders whether they have used tobacco production in the past 30 days. Almost all the increase comes from electronic cigarett. Among middle school students, the employment rate rose from 3.3 per cent in 2017 to 4.9 per cent last year. In order to make the right comparison, we must compare the electronic cigaret used only with the toxic tobacco products. There has been success in reducing the smoking of young people. In 2011, 6.4 per cent of middle school students said they smoked in the last 30 days; this fell to 3.3 per cent last year. During the same period, the use of electronic cigaret increased eight times, from 0.6 per cent in 2011 to 4.9 per cent last year. Among secondary school students, 21.9 per cent of smokers were in 2011 and fell to 13.9 per cent last year. However, over the same period, the use of electronic segarite increased from 1.5 per cent in 2011 to 20.8 per cent last year. In secondary schools, electronic segarit oversmoking occurred in 2014 as the most common type of smoking; the same happened in middle school a year later. Did their rise erase progress in curbing the smoking of young people, as Cain says? In other words, the number of smokers in secondary schools decreased by 1.2 million, while the number of smokers using electronic segarit increased by about 3.5 million. This is more than eliminating the progress made in reducing smoking over the past seven years. However, during his radio interview, Cain did not mention the CDC report, nor did he set a date for the commencement of his claim. If you go back 20 years or more to start measuring, progress will again appear. In 1997, 36.4 per cent of secondary school students - 5.2 million - said that they had smoked at least one cigarette over the past 30 days. This exceeds 27.1 per cent - or 4.5 million students - who reported using any tobacco product last year.
